document.docAuthor: Santos, Aluska Tavares Dos & Ribeiro-Costa, Cibele Stramare
document.masterDocTitle: Rearrangements in some species groups of Amblycerus Thunberg, 1815 (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae: Bruchinae) including keys, description of a new species, new host plant and distributional records

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Rearrangements in some species groups of Amblycerus Thunberg, 1815 (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae: Bruchinae) including keys, description of a new species, new host plant and distributional records

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material examined
. The species recognition was done through the
A. serieguttatus
original description and the work of Romero et al ., (1996) that includes male genitalia illustrations.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis ( Figs 20 , 33 , 112 )
.
Amblycerus serieguttatus
is characterized by the following combination of characters: eyes distant from each other anteriorly ( Fig. 33 ), ocular index: 4.0; elytra ( Fig. 20 ) with tufts of dense setae on interestriae 3, 5, 7, 9; median lobe of male genitalia about 3.6 times as long as its greatest width at apical region ( Fig. 112 ); internal sac with a pair of hollow, subcircular, tuberculate sclerites on the apical region ( Fig. 112 ); median region of internal sac with a pair of hand-shaped sclerites.
Amblycerus serieguttatus
is similar externally to
A. galapagoensis
, from which it differs in lateral carina almost reaching the posterior margin of pronotum (reaching the posterior margin of pronotum in
A. galapagoensis
) and scutellum tridentate, median tooth longer than the lateral ones (scutellum unidentate in
A. galapagoensis
). Other similar species is
A. luteonotatus
, belonging to the
luteonotatus
group ( Ribeiro-Costa 1995 ), but in
A. serieguttatus ,
the prosternal process, although expanded beyond the anterior coxae as in
A. luteonotatus
, does not reach the median legs, whereas it does reach the median legs in
A. luteonotatus
.

Distribution ( Fig. 122 )
. United States ( new country record ), Mexico , Guatemala , Nicaragua ( new country record ), Costa Rica , Panama , Venezuela , Trinidad and Tobago ( new country record ), and Argentina ( new country record ).
Life History . No information was found on this species in the literature.
